items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹668 â€” November 13, 2024 | Read on the web

Beautiful Focus Outlines â€” Thomas notes that focus outlines are often seen as a purely technical requirement, but suggests we should treat them as essential design elements that can help create â€œinterfaces that are both beautiful and inclusiveâ€, noting how they are fundamental to an accessible web. Also looks at a multi-colored striped approach, and a proposed native way to handling just that. Plenty of good examplesÂ here.

Thomas GÃ¼nther

A Recap of Google's Web AI Summit 2024 â€” Google recently held a summit specifically about the use of machine learning models directly in the browser, specifically by developers creating new, rich experiences for users. Itâ€™s interesting to see how things are progressing here and you can watch some of the talks onÂ YouTube.

Jason Mayes (Google)

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half theÂ Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like Ashby, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

An Official Logo for CSS â€” After hundreds of votes, CSS now has its own logo, moving beyond the shield and number combo of the CSS 3 era. Weâ€™ve got a main rebeccapurple version (pictured), along with a dark and lightÂ version.

CSS-Next Community Group

ğŸ’œ If you're unaware of the color 'rebeccapurple', the story of its presence in the CSS standard is aÂ touchingÂ one.

New CSS That Can Actually Be Used in 2024 â€” Yep, the amount of CSS changes and additions in the last two to four years has been staggering, as such this page (published earlier thisÂ year) is a good cheatsheet reminder, of sorts, for newer things we can do with CSS.

Thomasorus

A key difference to the well known Live Preview is that changes in the preview then reflect back in theÂ code.
